abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Private Power Utilities (TEC) Project
            for the Tata Electric Companies (TEC) in India. The physical
            objectives of the project were to increase TEC's peak
            generating capacity, reduce its dependence on the
            Maharashtra State Electricity Board (MSEB) for power to
            serve its consumers, reduce the average cost of generation
            in increasing the capacity utilization of TEC's
            existing thermal power plant at Trombay, mitigate the
            Sulphur dioxide emissions (SO2) from the coal and oil
            burning Trombay Unit 5, and improve system reliability and
            quality of supply in the Bombay area. The institutional and
            sectoral objectives were to: (i) support increased private
            sector participation in the supply of power; and (ii)
            encourage improved tariff structure and load management
            procedures for TEC's direct consumers. The performance
            of the Bank from project preparation through project
            completion was satisfactory. Borrower’s performance was
            satisfactory. The key lessons learned were as follows: (a)
            stringent design quality control in this case appears to
            have been lacking; (b) the experience in this project
            confirms the appropriateness of the Bank's current
            procedure for which investment projects with significant
            environmental issues i.e., to secure all the necessary
            environmental and other clearances from all concerned
            central and state government agencies, well ahead of the
            approval of any loan by the Bank; (c) for major equipment
            suppliers, linking payment to the furnishing of essential
            design information required for detailed engineering helped
            alleviate design coordination problems; and (d) (f) not only
            the implementing agency, but also other government
            departments involved in the approval or licensing processes,
            must be equally alive to the project implementation schedule
            and work in unison to meet the schedule.
